questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An OR > 1 with a CI not including 1 suggests a significant association. How many risk factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3

 

In the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant.

 

A high socioeconomic status does not pose a risk factor. Despite observing a positive correlation, the statistical significance is absent. Any correlation with a 95% confidence interval with the value of 1.0 is deemed as statistically insignificant. A value of 1.0 within this range implies that both factors can coexist without one being the cause of the other.

Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:

 

  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative (protective) association.

 

Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

There are three factors (early menarche, BRCA mutation, obesity), that have statistically significant associations with breast cancer according to the odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals provided.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Infertility
  2. Dysmenorrhea
  3. Vaginal discharge
  4. Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:

 

1. Infertility: Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.

 

2. Dysmenorrhea: Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.

 

Option B. 2, 3: While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.


Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: HRT to induce puberty

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral gonadectomy

 

  • This patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization (Prader 3 classification is used to describe the degree of virilization of external genitalia)

 

 

  • If a Y-chromosome is identified during evaluation of primary amenorrhoea, laparoscopic prophylactic gonadectomy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to eliminate the risk of malignancy as dysgenetic gonads have a very high risk of malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. HRT to induce puberty: After gonadectomy, then HRT can be given for secondary sexual development

 

Option D. Clitoroplasty and Option A. vaginoplasty and other surgeries to correct the virilization may be required but the immediate next step would be to do gonadectomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever there is 46XY with primary amenorrhoea, always gonadectomy needs to be done in view of high risk of malignancy in dysgenetic gonads

 

Ref: Speroff’s Textbook of Reproductive Medicine

questions.text: A woman who is using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) experiences white vaginal discharge without itching or a foul odor. The discharge causes yellow staining on her underwear. Upon examination, the discharge reveals the presence of typical lactobacilli and an acidic pH. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased normal vaginal discharge

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Leucorrhea (Increased vaginal discharge). Leucorrhea presents with excessive whitish, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge. It is non-irritant, no purulent and non-offensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents with itching and a white thick, curdy discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option D. Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia infection can by asymptomatic or present with discharge but is not associated with yellow discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased normal vaginal discharge, known as leucorrhea, can occur in women using oral contraceptive pills. This discharge is typically white or yellow, non-irritant, no purulent, no offensive, and associated with the presence of lactobacilli and an acidic pH.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. During one such session focused on India's National Immunization Program, you discuss with your colleagues about the range of vaccines included in the program. Which of the following vaccines is NOT currently part of India's National Immunization Program? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Influenza

 

  • The Influenza vaccine (commonly known as the Flu shot) has not yet been included in India's National Immunization Programme.
  • It's important to note that the Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is distinct from the viral Influenza (Flu) vaccine.
  • The HiB vaccine is included as part of the pentavalent vaccine (DPT + HiB + HepB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: The following groups of people must be screened for Ca cervix: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25 to 65-year-old females

 

Explanation:

 

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. The guidelines specify the following:

 

ACOG/ACS Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 25.
  • Ages 25 to 65:
    • HPV testing every 5 years (preferred).
    • HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years (acceptable).
    • Pap test alone every 3 years (acceptable).
  • Age >65: No testing required if a series of previous tests were normal.

 

WHO Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 30.
  • Primary mode of screening: HPV testing.
  • Frequency: Every 5 to 10 years.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. More than 65 years old: Screening is generally not required for women over 65 if they have had a series of normal screening results.

 

Option B. Less than 25 years old: Screening is not recommended for women under 25 according to ACOG/ACS guidelines.

 

Option D. Teenagers: Screening is not recommended for teenagers as cervical cancer is extremely rare in this age group and the benefits of screening do not outweigh the potential harms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with various acceptable methods and intervals as specified by the ACOG and ACS guidelines.

 

Ref: ACOG guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, WHO guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 634, 635.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from west Garo Hill district of Meghalaya presents to the Civil Hospital with intermittent fever, chills, and malaise. Laboratory findings confirm the diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria. The region is known for its Multidrug- resistant strains of P. falciparum. Which of the following antimalarial regimens is considered the most appropriate first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas with multidrug-resistant strains? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artemether plus lumefantrine

 

The Drug of choice treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

 Artemisinin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For P. falciparum malaria in regions with known drug resistance, artemether plus lumefantrine is the most effective first-line treatment, ensuring rapid and sustained clearance of the malaria parasite.

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

questions.text: A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The description of a frothy vaginal discharge and a "strawberry cervix" is characteristic of trichomoniasis vaginalis, a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The drug of choice for treating trichomoniasis is Metronidazole. This medication can be administered as a single high dose (2g) or in a lower dose (200mg three times daily for 7 days).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for treating candidiasis (yeast infections), not trichomoniasis. Candidiasis typically presents with a curdy white discharge rather than frothy discharge and is not associated with a strawberry cervix.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Tetracycline is an antibiotic used for various bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis. It is not the drug of choice for treating this parasitic infection.

 

Option D. Cefixime: Cefixime is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections like gonorrhea. It is not effective against trichomoniasis and thus is not appropriate for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating trichomoniasis vaginalis, which presents with frothy vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix, is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles - 1, Vit. A -1

questions.text: A pediatrician in a remote village encounters an 18-month-old child with no vaccination history. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which set of vaccines should the child receive? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles -1, Vit. A - 1

 

  • According to India's National Immunization Schedule (NIS), an 18-month-old child who has not received any immunizations should be given their initial doses of DPT, OPV, measles vaccine, and vitamin A.

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case studies

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria engulfed by macrophages
﻿﻿﻿Neutrophil engulfed bacteria
﻿﻿﻿Bacteria arranged in clusters

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

 

The microscopic finding described is consistent with "clue cells," which are a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis (BV). Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are covered with a stippled appearance due to bacteria adhering to their surface. This attachment creates a poorly defined border on the cell. Clue cells are significant in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis because they are a reliable indicator of this condition. For a diagnosis of BV, at least 20 percent of epithelial cells in a wet mount preparation should appear as clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding is more indicative of an inflammatory response and is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly associated with other types of infections or inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: This description is associated with acute bacterial infections or inflammation but not with bacterial vaginosis, where clue cells are the key finding.

 

Option D. Bacteria arranged in clusters: While bacteria may be present in clusters in some infections, this description does not specifically identify the clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells, which are epithelial cells with bacteria attached on their surface, are the most reliable microscopic indicator of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Cervical mucus thickening
Increase GnRH release

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.

 

Mechanisms of action of OCPs:

 

  • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.

 

Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.

 

Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition 485

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Among the following which is considered as water borne hepatitis virus? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Hepatitis A virus

 

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is considered waterborne because it is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. 
  • Out of the five major types of hepatitis viruses, only Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the feco-oral route. 
  • This means they can be transmitted through contaminated water and food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis B is not waterborne. Hepatitis B is transmitted through sexual contact, needle syringes, parenteral route, and blood (including blood products). 

 

Option C. Hepatitis C virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis C is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual contact, needle sharing, and blood. 

 

Option D. Hepatitis D virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis D is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual, parenteral (needles), and blood routes, similar to Hepatitis B and C

 

Educational Objective:

 

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‘the best predictors of state failure’
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

choices.text: Ascending aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Episiotomy scissors

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument given in the picture is an episiotomy scissors.
  • The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.
  • An episiotomy is NOT given routinely.
  • It’s use is restricted and is given in situations like.
    • Macrosomia
    • After coming head of breech
    • Instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Curved artery: It has serrated tips and ratchet lock . It is used to clamp blood vessels, hold peritoneal edges, tissue dissection

 

 

Option C. Curved mayo scissors: These are used to cut tissue such as the uterus, rectus sheath etc.

 

 

Option D. Mosquito forceps: It is a small artery forceps used to catch small bleeders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed with an angulated blade to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins, thereby reducing the risk of obstetric anal sphincter injuries and complete perineal tears during childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 755

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Herpes Zoster 

 

  • While Herpes Zoster (shingles) can be contagious, it primarily requires contact precautions unless disseminated or in the immunocompromised, where it might necessitate airborne precautions if there are pulmonary symptoms.
  • Generally, for localized shingles in an immunocompetent patient, standard precautions along with contact precautions are sufficient, thus not routinely requiring airborne precautions like the diseases listed in the other options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Requires airborne precautions due to the high risk of transmission through airborne particles, particularly the respiratory droplets that can suspend in the air for extended periods.

 

Option C. Measles: Highly contagious and spreads through airborne transmission. Airborne precautions are essential due to measles' ability to remain airborne for up to two hours after the infected person has left the area.

 

Option D. Chicken Pox (Varicella): Also spread through airborne transmission, requiring similar precautions to measles to prevent the spread of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

choices.text: Metronidazole
Fluconazole
Clindamycin

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of pregnant woman with bacterial vaginosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis (BV) in pregnant women. This choice is based on its efficacy in addressing the anaerobic bacterial overgrowth that characterizes BV. It is generally prescribed as 200 mg three times daily for 7 days during pregnancy. While Clindamycin is also used for BV and can be an alternative, Metronidazole remains the preferred treatment due to its effectiveness and established safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluconazole: This drug is used for the treatment of fungal infections like candidiasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for BV, especially if Metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, Metronidazole is typically preferred.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is generally used for various bacterial infections but is not the first choice for BV. It is not typically used for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. The biopsy will help in diagnosing the nature of the lesion, which is crucial for further management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization is an excisional procedure done once biopsy-proven intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step when a visible lesion is present and needs to be assessed.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure done for CIN 1 or 2. It is not suitable for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding without a prior biopsy.

 

Option D. Pap smear: Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. In the presence of a visible mass, a direct biopsy is more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a symptomatic patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the cervix, the next step is a targeted biopsy to diagnose the nature of the lesion.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg662, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg345

choices.text: MgSO4
Nifedipine
Ritoridine

questions.text: In preterm labor which drug has a neuro-protective role? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MgSO4

 

Explanation:

 

Neuroprotection in preterm labor:

 

  • The drug given is MgSO4.
  • It reduces the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay.
  • IV MgSO4 should be offered for neuroprotection of the baby to all women between 24+0 and 29+6 weeks who are:
    • In established preterm labor or
    • Having a planned preterm birth within 24 hours.
  • It can be considered for neuroprotection of the baby for women between 30+0 and 33+6 weeks.
  • Dose: 4 g intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate over 15 minutes, followed by an intravenous infusion of 1 g per hour until the birth or for 24 hours (whichever is sooner).

 

Uses of MgSO4 in Obstetrics:

 

  1. Treatment of Eclampsia (Anti-seizure)
  2. Prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia (to prevent eclampsia)
  3. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  4. As a neuroprotective drug in preterm labor (especially < 30 weeks)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker used as a tocolytic and antihypertensive but has no role in neuroprotection.

 

Option C. Ritodrine: A beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic but has no neuroprotective role.

 

Option D. Isoxsuprine: Another beta-sympathomimetic used as a tocolytic without neuroprotective properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm labor, MgSO4 is used for neuroprotection, reducing the incidence of cerebral palsy and neurodevelopmental delay in preterm infants.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 538

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO Recommendations 2018 for the intrapartum second stage of labor emphasize the importance of a positive birth experience. The guidelines suggest manual support to the perineum to maintain the flexion of the fetal head, which helps in reducing perineal trauma.

 

WHO Recommendations 2018 (Intrapartum Second Stage):

 

Recommended:

 

  • Duration of the second stage in primigravida: up to 3 hours; in multigravida: up to 2 hours
  • Allowing the birthing position of choice
  • Encouraging the mother to follow her own urge to push
  • Reducing perineal trauma by using techniques such as hands-on guarding, warm compresses, and perineal massage

 

Not recommended:

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Other options:
