Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: This is not recommended as a routine practice according to WHO guidelines. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This is incorrect. Warm compresses to the perineum are recommended to help reduce perineal trauma.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines recommend allowing the woman to choose her birthing position, rather than mandating the lithotomy position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manual support to the perineum and maintaining the flexion of the fetal head are part of the WHO recommendations for the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma and ensure a positive birth experience.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was admitted to a tertiary care hospital in New Delhi following a fall at home. During her stay, the nursing staff consistently followed protocols for waste segregation. Based on the guidelines for biomedical waste management, which type of waste should be correctly disposed of in the following mentioned bag? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Urine Bag

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical waste: Anatomical wastes is disposed in yellow bin.

 

Option C. Soiled waste: Soiled wastes are disposed in yellow bin.

 

Option D. Sharp waste: Sharp wastes are disposed in white puncture proof, leak-proof, tamper-proof white containers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The red biohazard bag is used for the disposal of Contaminated plastic recyclable waste like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles) and gloves

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for diagnosing abdominal pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • Studdiford Criteria is for diagnosis of Primary abdominal pregnancy
    • Both tubes and ovaries normal with no marks of injury
    • Utero-peritoneal fistula should not be seen
    • The placenta should be attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiegelberg Criteria: Spiegelberg Criteria is for Ovarian ectopic

 

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestation sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • The gestation sac in the ovary must be connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall on histopathology

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Rubin criteria is for Cervical pregnancy

 

Option D. Ring of fire: Ring of fire is a sign seen on USG-Color doppler in an unruptured tubal ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

Studdiford Criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. This criterion involves:

 

  1. Ensuring that both fallopian tubes and ovaries are normal with no signs of injury.
  2. Confirming that no utero-peritoneal fistula is present.
  3. Verifying that the placenta is attached exclusively to the peritoneal surface.

 

These criteria help distinguish primary abdominal pregnancy from other types of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Ref: Page no 219, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes
Clear colorless to pale yellow

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

 

Explanation:

 

The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:

 

  • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.

 

Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.

 

Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.

 

Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

choices.text: Contraction stress test

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Contraction stress test

 

The fetal biophysical profile (BPP) is a comprehensive assessment used to evaluate fetal well-being, and it includes five components:

 

  1. NST (Non-Stress Test): Evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): Assessed through ultrasound to check the amount of amniotic fluid.
  3. Fetal Movement: Observes fetal movements through ultrasound.
  4. Fetal Tone: Evaluates the presence of fetal muscle tone and limb movements.
  5. Fetal Breathing: Assesses the presence and duration of fetal breathing movements.

 

The Contraction Stress Test (CST) is not part of the BPP. Instead, it is a separate test used to assess the fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, helping to evaluate how well the fetus handles the stress of contractions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal movement: This is a component of the BPP, assessing the number of fetal movements.

 

Option B. Fetal breathing: This is a component of the BPP, evaluating the presence of fetal breathing movements.

 

Option C. NST: The Non-Stress Test is a key component of the BPP, measuring fetal heart rate reactivity to movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Contraction Stress Test is not a component of the fetal biophysical profile.

 

Ref: Page no 122, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Before 34 weeks

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that develops before 34 weeks of gestation. 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia:

 

  • Indicates potentially higher severity
  • Is associated with conditions like antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Can be prevented by administering low-dose aspirin

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before 34 weeks of gestation, while late-onset pre-eclampsia occurs after 34 weeks.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

 

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

 

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Ask for line probe assay: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. Wait until TB culture results to start ATT: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As a physician on a disaster preparedness committee in a region prone to natural disasters, you are discussing the appropriate sequence of actions following a disaster. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the appropriate steps in disaster management after the event has taken place? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction – Mitigation – Preparedness

 

The correct sequence after a disaster as per the general disaster management principles is:

 

  1. Response: Immediate actions taken to ensure safety, provide emergency services, and stabilize the situation. This involves –
    • Search, rescue and first aid
    • Field care
    • Triage
    • Tagging
    • Identification of dead
  2. Rehabilitation: Short-term recovery and normalization of operations to restore basic services and functions in the affected area.
  3. Reconstruction: Long-term rebuilding of infrastructure and restoration of a fully functional community.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the risk and lessen the impact of future disasters.
  5. Preparedness: Planning and preparation to improve response activities for future disasters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disaster Cycle

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • Standard deviation is the Root of Mean od Squares of Deviations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance: Variance = (Standard deviation)2

 

Option C. Mean: Mean is obtained as sum of all values divided by the number of values in the distribution. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median: Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard deviation measures the dispersion of a data set around its mean.

choices.text: Activated protein C

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described—postpartum hemorrhage followed by severe headache, visual changes, hypotension, and unresponsiveness—suggests Sheehan syndrome. This condition arises from pituitary apoplexy, which is pituitary infarction secondary to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

  • Sheehan Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland failure due to substantial blood loss during delivery. The symptoms include persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, lactation failure, headache, visual deficits, and in severe cases, shock, CNS hemorrhage, and even death.
  • Steroids: Hormone replacement with glucocorticoids (steroids) is crucial for managing Sheehan syndrome. Steroids address the adrenal insufficiency and help stabilize the patient’s condition. Initially, glucocorticoids are administered, followed by other hormone replacements as needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Dobutamine: Dobutamine is a beta-agonist used for managing cardiac failure and hypotension. While it may help with blood pressure, it does not address the underlying issue of pituitary failure and would not be the primary treatment for Sheehan syndrome.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone used in thyroid hormone replacement therapy. While it might be needed later if thyroid function is affected, it does not directly address the acute symptoms of Sheehan syndrome, which is primarily managed with steroids.

 

Option D. Activated Protein C: Activated protein C is used in the management of severe sepsis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it does not treat the pituitary dysfunction associated with Sheehan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is treated primarily with glucocorticoid (steroid) therapy to manage pituitary failure following significant blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

Ref: Page 378, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

choices.text: Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle
Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck
The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle
The movement by which the head is born

questions.text: What is restitution? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck

 

Restitution is one of the cardinal movements of labor that occurs after the delivery of the fetal head. During internal rotation, the fetal neck gets twisted by 45 degrees (for example, in Left Occipital Anterior position). Once the head is delivered and free from the bony confines of the pelvis, it naturally untwists to align with the fetal body. This untwisting movement of the head is called restitution.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle: Incorrect. Restitution isn't defined by the degree of rotation (though a 45-degree rotation is approximately 1/8th of a circle). Rather, restitution specifically refers to the untwisting mechanism and its purpose.

 

Option C. The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle: Incorrect. Shoulder rotation occurs after restitution and is part of a different cardinal step called external rotation. During external rotation, the shoulders enter the pelvis and undergo internal rotation, which manifests as the head rotating externally.

 

Option D. The movement by which the head is born: Incorrect. This describes extension, which is the movement that occurs when the head is being delivered, before restitution takes place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restitution is the untwisting movement of the fetal head that occurs after delivery of the head, correcting the twist that occurred during internal rotation.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

choices.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug
90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

 

  • A P-value of less than 0.10 suggests that the likelihood of the drug's benefits occurring due to chance is no higher than 10%.

 

 INTERPRETATION:

 

  • Out of 100 repeated tests, a statistically insignificant difference will occur only 10 times, while a statistically significant difference will emerge 90 times.
  • There is a 10% probability of incorrectly concluding that a drug is beneficial when it is not, which can happen in statistical studies when deciding whether to accept or reject a null hypothesis.
  • The P value is compared to a predetermined threshold value 'a'; if the P value is less than 'a', the test is considered statistically significant, and the null hypothesis is rejected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

choices.text: MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 8 months
MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months
MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

questions.text: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

 

Option C : MR Sc and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months:

 

Explanation

 

This option is correct as per the National Immunization Schedule. The MR vaccine is given subcutaneously at 9 completed months along with the first dose of Vitamin A, aligning with the guidelines for both treatments.

 

Vitamin A Supplementation schedule

 

 

In total – 9 doses – 17 Lacs IU

 

Measles vaccine schedule

 

 

Educational objective :

 

The MR vaccine should be administered subcutaneously at 9 completed months, and the first dose of Vitamin A should be given concurrently. This regimen helps to ensure optimal immune response and nutritional support, which is crucial for preventing measles, rubella, and vitamin A deficiency-related health issues.

questions.text: Best level of evidence as seen in research is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Meta-analysis

 

  • Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine (EBM) pyramid. 
  • Meta-analysis is defined in a very unique way that is “Analysis of Analyses”- Analysis of multiple studies together. 
  • It is considered the gold standard of evidence-based medicine and is the most superior epidemiological study design.
  • The concept of evidence-based medicine was introduced by D.L. Sackett, who is known as the father of evidence-based medicine. 
  • When organizing studies from the worst to the best in terms of strength of evidence, meta-analysis sits at the top of the EBM pyramid, followed by systematic reviews, randomized control trials (RCTs), cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, ecological studies, then opinion views, animal research, and finally in vitro research at the bottom.


 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: While cohort studies provide strong evidence and are higher in the EBM pyramid than case-control studies, they are still below meta-analyses and RCTs. Cohort studies follow groups of people over time to determine if exposure to certain factors leads to specific outcomes. They can establish temporality but may have issues with loss to follow-up and are time-consuming.

 

 

Option B. Case control study: These are lower in the EBM hierarchy compared to cohort studies, RCTs, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses. Case-control studies compare cases (people with a condition) with controls (people without the condition) to identify potential risk factors. They are retrospective and subject to recall bias.

 

Option C. RCT (Randomized Control Trial): Though RCTs are considered the gold standard for evaluating interventions and are high in the EBM pyramid, they are still ranked below meta-analyses and systematic reviews. RCTs randomly assign participants to treatment or control groups, minimizing selection bias, but they may not always be generalizable to all populations.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine hierarchy, above systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, and case-control studies.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by sandflies? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Trench fever

 

Trench fever is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

 

Points to remember about Sandfly - 

 

  • Sandfly cannot fly; it hops
  • Sandfly rests in cracks and crevices of walls
  • Insecticide of choice: 

 

DDT - 2 rounds of spray per year; Spray up to 6 feet height on walls; 

 

If DDT–resistant, use BHC 

 

  • Sandfly is the vector of:
    • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala azar) (by Female Phlebotamus argentipes)
    • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Oriental Sore) & Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (by Phlebotamus papatasi & Phlebotamus sergenti)
    • Sandfly Fever
    • Oroya Fever
  • Sandflies inject the infective stage, metacyclic promastigotes, during blood meals.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vectors and Diseases Transmitted
